name: BNY Mellon
title: BNY Mellon Scales the 'Agentic Era' with Deployment of 20000 AI Assistants
description:
In a move that signals a tectonic shift in the digital transformation of global finance, BNY (NYSE: BNY), formerly known as BNY Mellon, has officially reached a massive milestone in its AI strategy.
BNY has engineered Eliza to be model-agnostic, allowing agents to switch between different high-performance models based on the specific task.
Initial reactions from the AI research community have been overwhelmingly positive, particularly regarding BNY’s commitment to "Explainable AI" (XAI).
The New Standard for Institutional Finance The deployment of 20,000 AI agents at BNY marks the definitive end of the "experimentation phase" for generative AI in the financial sector.
The key takeaways are clear: agentic AI is no longer a futuristic concept; it is an active, revenue-impacting reality.
text:
In a move that signals a tectonic shift in the digital transformation of global finance, BNY (NYSE: BNY), formerly known as BNY Mellon, has officially reached a massive milestone in its AI strategy. As of January 16, 2026, the world’s largest custody bank has successfully deployed tens of thousands of "Agentic Assistants" across its global operations. This deployment represents one of the first successful transitions from experimental generative AI to a full-scale "agentic" operating model, where AI systems perform complex, autonomous tasks rather than just responding to prompts.

The bank’s initiative, built upon its proprietary Eliza platform, has divided its AI workforce into two distinct categories: over 20,000 "Empowered Builders"—human employees trained to create custom agents—and a growing fleet of over 130 specialized "Digital Employees." These digital entities possess their own system credentials, email accounts, and communication access, effectively operating as autonomous members of the bank’s workforce. This development is being hailed as the "operating system of the bank," fundamentally altering how BNY handles trillions of dollars in assets daily.

Technical Deep Dive: From Chatbots to Digital Employees

The technical backbone of this initiative is the Eliza 2.0 platform, a sophisticated multi-agent orchestration layer that represents a departure from the simple Large Language Model (LLM) interfaces of 2023 and 2024. Unlike previous iterations that focused on text generation, Eliza 2.0 is centered on "reasoning" and "agency." These agents are not just processing data; they are executing workflows that involve multiple steps, such as cross-referencing internal databases, validating external regulatory updates, and communicating findings via Microsoft Teams to their human managers.

A critical component of this deployment is the "menu of models" approach. BNY has engineered Eliza to be model-agnostic, allowing agents to switch between different high-performance models based on the specific task. For instance, agents might use GPT-4 from OpenAI for complex logical reasoning, Google Cloud’s Gemini Enterprise for multimodal deep research, and specialized Llama-based models for internal code remediation. This architecture ensures that the bank is not locked into a single provider while maximizing the unique strengths of each AI ecosystem.

Initial reactions from the AI research community have been overwhelmingly positive, particularly regarding BNY’s commitment to "Explainable AI" (XAI). Every agentic model must pass a rigorous "Model-Risk Review" before deployment, generating detailed "model cards" and feature importance charts that allow auditors to understand the "why" behind an agent's decision. This level of transparency addresses a major hurdle in the adoption of AI within highly regulated environments, where "black-box" decision-making is often a non-starter for compliance officers.

The Multi-Vendor Powerhouse: Big Tech's Role in the Agentic Shift

The scale of BNY's deployment has created a lucrative blueprint for major technology providers. Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) played a foundational role by supplying the hardware infrastructure; BNY was the first major bank to deploy an Nvidia DGX SuperPOD with H100 systems, providing the localized compute power necessary to train and run these agents securely on-premises. This partnership has solidified Nvidia’s position not just as a chipmaker, but as a critical infrastructure partner for "Sovereign AI" within the private sector.

Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) and Alphabet (NASDAQ: GOOGL) are also deeply integrated into the Eliza ecosystem. Microsoft Azure hosts much of the Eliza infrastructure, providing the integration layer for agents to interact with the Microsoft 365 suite, including Outlook and Teams. Meanwhile, Google Cloud’s Gemini Enterprise is being utilized for "agentic deep research," synthesizing vast datasets to provide predictive analytics on trade settlements. This competitive landscape shows that while tech giants are vying for dominance, the "agentic era" is fostering a multi-provider reality where enterprise clients demand interoperability and the ability to leverage the best-of-breed models from various labs.

For AI startups, BNY’s move is both a challenge and an opportunity. While the bank has the resources to build its own orchestration layer, the demand for specialized, niche agents—such as those focused on specific international tax laws or ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) compliance—is expected to create a secondary market for smaller AI firms that can plug into platforms like Eliza. The success of BNY’s internal "Empowered Builders" program suggests that the future of enterprise AI may lie in tools that allow non-technical staff to build and maintain their own agents, rather than relying on off-the-shelf software.

Reshaping the Global Finance Landscape

The broader significance of BNY’s move cannot be overstated. By empowering 40% of its global workforce to build and use AI agents, the bank has effectively democratized AI in a way that parallels the introduction of the personal computer or the spreadsheet. This is a far cry from the pilot projects of 2024; it is a full-scale industrialization of AI. BNY has reported a roughly 5% reduction in unit costs for core custody trades, a significant margin in the high-volume, low-margin world of asset servicing.

Beyond cost savings, the deployment addresses the increasing complexity of regulatory compliance. BNY’s "Contract Review Assistant" agents can now benchmark thousands of negotiated agreements against global regulations in a fraction of the time it would take human legal teams. This "always-on" compliance capability mitigates risk and allows the bank to adapt to shifting geopolitical and regulatory landscapes with unprecedented speed.

Comparisons are already being drawn to previous technological milestones, such as the transition to electronic trading in the 1990s. However, the agentic shift is potentially more disruptive because it targets the "cognitive labor" of the middle and back office. While earlier waves of automation replaced manual data entry, these agents are performing tasks that previously required human judgment and cross-departmental coordination. The potential concern remains the "human-in-the-loop" requirement; as agents become more autonomous, the pressure on human managers to supervise dozens of digital employees will require new management frameworks and training.

The Next Frontier: Proactive Agents and Automated Remediation

Looking toward the remainder of 2026 and into 2027, the bank is expected to expand the capabilities of its agents from reactive to proactive. Near-term developments include "Predictive Trade Analytics," where agents will not only identify settlement risks but also autonomously initiate remediation protocols to prevent trade failures before they occur. This move from "detect and report" to "anticipate and act" will be the true test of agentic autonomy in finance.

One of the most anticipated applications on the horizon is the integration of these agents into client-facing roles. While currently focused on internal operations, BNY is reportedly exploring "Client Co-pilots" that would give the bank’s institutional clients direct access to agentic research and analysis tools. However, this will require addressing significant challenges regarding data privacy and "multi-tenant" agent security to ensure that agents do not inadvertently share proprietary insights across different client accounts.

Experts predict that other "Global Systemically Important Banks" (G-SIBs) will be forced to follow suit or risk falling behind in operational efficiency. We are likely to see a "space race" for AI talent and compute resources, as institutions realize that the "Agentic Assistant" model is the only way to manage the exponential growth of financial data and regulatory requirements in the late 2020s.

The New Standard for Institutional Finance

The deployment of 20,000 AI agents at BNY marks the definitive end of the "experimentation phase" for generative AI in the financial sector. The key takeaways are clear: agentic AI is no longer a futuristic concept; it is an active, revenue-impacting reality. BNY’s success with the Eliza platform demonstrates that with the right governance, infrastructure, and multi-vendor strategy, even the most traditional financial institutions can reinvent themselves for the AI era.

This development will likely be remembered as a turning point in AI history—the moment when "agents" moved from tech demos to the front lines of global capitalism. In the coming weeks and months, the industry will be watching closely for BNY’s quarterly earnings to see how these efficiencies translate into bottom-line growth. Furthermore, the response from regulators like the Federal Reserve and the SEC will be crucial in determining how fast other institutions are allowed to adopt similar autonomous systems.

As we move further into 2026, the question is no longer whether AI will change finance, but which institutions will have the infrastructure and the vision to lead the agentic revolution. BNY has made its move, setting a high bar for the rest of the industry to follow.

This content is intended for informational purposes only and represents analysis of current AI developments.

title: Novo Nordisk Shares Jump 4.6% on UK Approval of Higher-Dose Wegovy
description:
Novo Nordisk A/S shares surged in U.S. trading after U.K. regulators cleared a triple-dose of the company’s flagship obesity drug, heightening rivalry with Eli Lilly & Co. in the $100 billion weight-loss market.
Registered Office: 89 Nexus Way, Camana Bay, Grand Cayman, Cayman Islands KY1-9009.
Capital Markets Elite Group does not accept securities trading accounts for any “U.S.
Persons” that it believes have been “solicited” by Capital Markets Elite Group within the meaning of Rule 15a-6(a)(1) of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.
© Copyright 2025 Capital Markets Elite Group – All Rights Reserved
text:
Novo Nordisk A/S shares surged in U.S. trading after U.K. regulators cleared a triple-dose of the company’s flagship obesity drug, heightening rivalry with Eli Lilly & Co. in the $100 billion weight-loss market.

The Danish drugmaker’s American depositary receipts climbed 3.2% in premarket trading Friday following the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency’s approval of a 7.2-milligram weekly dose of semaglutide—three times the previous 2.4-mg limit. The higher dose requires three separate injections and is restricted to adult patients with obesity. Eli Lilly shares dipped 0.3%.

Market Dynamics Shift

The approval comes as Novo encounters increasing pressure from Lilly’s Zepbound, which has achieved considerable market share despite Novo’s early-mover position with semaglutide-based treatments. Ozempic received FDA approval for Type 2 diabetes in 2017, with Wegovy following for chronic weight management in 2021.

Novo’s counterstrategy centers on product diversification. The company launched an oral Wegovy formulation in the U.S. on January 5, with a U.K. regulatory decision anticipated by year-end.

Revenue Projections

Speaking at this week’s J.P. Morgan Healthcare Conference, Novo CEO Mike Doustdar pointed out the oral medication’s strategic importance. “Right now, we are being judged by how many patients are being switched between Eli Lilly and us,” Doustdar said. “A big part of those people don’t want an injection. They’re waiting for the pill.”

Berenberg analysts project the oral version could generate approximately $1 billion in 2025 revenue, possibly counterbalancing headwinds from U.S. pricing pressures and patent expirations. The bank’s base-case scenario forecasts $2 billion by 2027, with upside potential to $6 billion if Novo leverages its first-mover advantage.

Competitive Landscape

Lilly is developing orforglipron, an oral GLP-1 competitor expected to launch this year following last month’s FDA application submission. December data showed orforglipron enables patients to maintain weight loss after transitioning from injectable treatments, including Wegovy and Zepbound, with participants switching directly from maximum tolerated injectable doses to oral formulations.

text:
Johnson & Johnson (NYSE:JNJ) is among the most profitable US stocks to buy. On January 9, Lee Hambright at Bernstein raised the price target on Johnson & Johnson (NYSE:JNJ) to $208 from $193 and kept the ‘Market Perform’ rating unchanged, according to TheFly.

The firm noted that U.S. healthcare stocks have shown improved performance over the last few months, following a low point in September 2025. With clearer visibility into macroeconomic uncertainties that have challenged healthcare stocks throughout 2025, Bernstein has a more favorable outlook for 2026.

Trong Nguyen / Shutterstock.com

Three days earlier, on January 6, Stifel also raised the price target on Johnson & Johnson (NYSE:JNJ) to $205 from $190, keeping a ‘Hold’ rating on the stock. This upward revision in target follows the company’s completion of its approximately $3.05 billion acquisition of Halda Therapeutics on December 29, 2025.

Stifel highlighted that the Halda acquisition is projected to be dilutive to Johnson & Johnson’s (NYSE:JNJ) adjusted earnings per share by a total of $0.20, with $0.10 of the impact in each of 2025 and 2026.

Johnson & Johnson (NYSE:JNJ) is a global healthcare company focused on innovative medicines and medical technologies. Headquartered in New Jersey, the company serves a wide clientele, including retailers, wholesalers, healthcare professionals, and hospitals.

While we acknowledge the potential of JNJ as an investment, we believe certain AI stocks offer greater upside potential and carry less downside risk. text:
Cabin Configuration & Seat Layout

Delta’s Embraer E175 carries 76 passengers in this three-cabin layout tailored for higher-demand regional routes. The aircraft operates with a 12-seat First Class cabin in a 1-2 configuration, offering a clearly defined premium section with wider seats and more personalized service. Behind it, 20 Delta Comfort+ seats transition into the 44-seat Main Cabin, both using the E175's signature 2-2 layout. This four-abreast design makes seat selection straightforward for traveling couples, who can have a block of seats to themselves on either side of the aisle in economy class.

Interior Image

Seat Dimensions & Amenities

Seat comfort is consistent across the E175 thanks to similar widths, with differentiation coming mainly from legroom and service level.

First Class: 20″ width, 36″ pitch; larger recliners, more legroom, and priority stowage.

Delta Comfort+: 18.3″ width, 34″ pitch; extra legroom and forward placement for quicker boarding and exit.

Approach 2: Maplebear Price vs Earnings For profitable companies, the P/E ratio is a useful way to think about value because it links what you pay for each share with the earnings that back it.
What counts as a “normal” P/E depends on how the market views a company’s growth potential and risk.
Higher expected growth or lower perceived risk can justify a higher multiple, while slower expected growth or higher perceived risk can mean a lower one is more reasonable.
This Fair Ratio can be more informative than a plain comparison with peers or the industry, because it is tailored to Maplebear’s own characteristics rather than broad group averages.
Comparing the current P/E of 20.70x with the Fair Ratio of 19.03x suggests the shares are trading above that tailored estimate.
text:
Approach 2: Maplebear Price vs Earnings

For profitable companies, the P/E ratio is a useful way to think about value because it links what you pay for each share with the earnings that back it. It is essentially the price tag on each dollar of profit.

What counts as a “normal” P/E depends on how the market views a company’s growth potential and risk. Higher expected growth or lower perceived risk can justify a higher multiple, while slower expected growth or higher perceived risk can mean a lower one is more reasonable.

Maplebear currently trades on a P/E of 20.70x. That sits below both the Consumer Retailing industry average of about 21.59x and the peer group average of 28.82x. Simply Wall St also calculates a proprietary “Fair Ratio” of 19.03x for Maplebear, which is the P/E level suggested by factors such as its earnings growth profile, industry, profit margins, market capitalization and risk indicators.

This Fair Ratio can be more informative than a plain comparison with peers or the industry, because it is tailored to Maplebear’s own characteristics rather than broad group averages. Comparing the current P/E of 20.70x with the Fair Ratio of 19.03x suggests the shares are trading above that tailored estimate.

Result: OVERVALUED

P/E ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Discover 1442 companies where insiders are betting big on explosive growth.

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Maplebear Narrative

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation. Narratives on Simply Wall St let you write your own story for Maplebear by tying your assumptions about its future revenue, earnings and margins to a forecast and a Fair Value, then comparing that Fair Value to the current price. The platform, used by millions of investors through the Community page, keeps your Narrative updated when new information such as news or earnings arrives. One investor might build a Narrative closer to the higher analyst price target of US$67.00 with stronger growth and profitability assumptions, while another might lean toward the lower target of US$42.00 with more cautious expectations. Both can clearly see how their different stories translate into different estimates of what the shares may be worth and how that lines up with today’s price.

Do you think there's more to the story for Maplebear? Head over to our Community to see what others are saying!

We aim to bring you long-term focused analysis driven by fundamental data. Note that our analysis may not factor in the latest price-sensitive company announcements or qualitative material. name: Boston Scientific
title: Unlocking Opportunities in Asia's Medical Device Market
description:
Medical device manufacturers can’t afford not to consider entering potentially lucrative Asian markets.
For non-Asian medical device manufacturers trying to expand into Asian markets, having the right mindset from the beginning helps, Khong told MD+DI.
In essence, the approach ensures that device manufacturers rely on the local supply chain, local components, local packaging — everything local, Khong said.
Rewards to reap Medical device companies will likely face many challenges initially when they start their journeys to access Asian markets.
In the medical device manufacturing category, Japan was the largest and India the fastest-growing market in 2024.
text:
Medical device manufacturers can’t afford not to consider entering potentially lucrative Asian markets. Reported to be about $31.77 billion in 2024, the Asia Pacific medical device contract manufacturing market is expected to reach $100.90 billion by 2033, according to a report by Grand View Research.

Medical device manufacturers based in the United States and Europe, however, find that the road to market approval in Asian countries is complicated, differs by country, and requires local alliances or partnerships.

Right mindset for starters

Asia should not be treated as a single, homogeneous market. Rather, Asia is made up of several distinct regions with different regulatory maturity, market behavior, and go-to-market requirements, according to Meng Khong, U.S. CEO of SotaTek, a health-technology development firm that helps bridge gaps for medical device and other industry players’ access in and out of Asia and Singapore.

For non-Asian medical device manufacturers trying to expand into Asian markets, having the right mindset from the beginning helps, Khong told MD+DI. For example, don’t think that having FDA clearance or European Union market approval is an in. It’s not. And don’t think that once you’re in a part of Asia, your product will have easy access to all Asian markets. It won’t.

“Because of these differences, companies that succeed in Asia typically design or redesign their products with specific regional and local contexts in mind, rather than assuming a single FDA-cleared or globally approved product can be lightly localized and deployed across all Asian markets,” he said.

Eyes wide open

Understanding local market requirements and policies and having strategies in place are key, he said.

“When you go into a local market, you need to test according to the local environment and user scenarios. Not all the Asian markets have good Wi-Fi, for example. And all have different data regulatory requirements. For example, Indonesia and China cannot allow patients’ data to go out of the country,” he said.

As Asia’s number one manufacturing destination, China is a worthy market, with a huge population and an insatiable hunger for medical device technology — notably wearables. China’s regulatory requirements, however, make for “an extensive and painful experience,” which often means designing and manufacturing a device from the ground up, according to Khong.

Companies like San Diego, CA-based Illumina opted instead to establish a hub in Singapore, paving the way to an easier entry into the Chinese market. Singapore, South Korea, and Japan are stable, predictable, more open markets. Companies like to establish regional hubs in those countries because there are few surprises. Regulatory requirements are pretty predictable, according to Khong.

Right now, probably 60% of medical device company regional hubs are being set up in Singapore, Khong said. Medtronic, GE HealthCare, and Siemens Healthineers have hubs there.

China’s rules, on the other hand, favor a made-in-China strategy. Khong said there are several terms used to refer to the strategy, including China Localization 2.0 (supply chain and technology localization) and “Made in China 2025” (industrial localization), among others. In essence, the approach ensures that device manufacturers rely on the local supply chain, local components, local packaging — everything local, Khong said.

According to an October 13, 2025, China Briefing, “China’s new government procurement policy introduces a 20 percent price evaluation advantage for qualifying domestic products and sets clearer standards for what counts as ‘Made in China.’ This poses real challenges for foreign businesses — especially those with offshore production — but also creates a more transparent and fairer competitive environment. To stay competitive, companies should proactively localize production, strengthen compliance systems, and align with evolving standards to seize new opportunities in China’s vast public procurement market.”

Potentially good news is China also has the China Plus One, or C+1, policy, which encourages investment (manufacturing and supply chain operations) not only in China but also in other Asian countries, according to Source of Asia.

This is to avoid overreliance on a single source country, and can help U.S. and European medical device manufacturers who have established hubs in these partnering countries to help gain access to the China market.

Countries like Malaysia, Thailand, India, and Vietnam are among the countries actively positioning themselves for China Plus One. Malaysia is a long-established medical device manufacturing hub, according to Khong.

More encouraging news: once medical device manufacturers from abroad get over the initial regulatory hurdles, testing their devices on humans may not be as big a deal as in the United States.

For example, China is big in wearable devices and has many more brands than the United States, according to Khong.

“The U.S. is much more regulated, and devices have to go through a longer experimental cycle before being launched in the market. In Asia, the common practice is that they do have regulations, but they tend to have devices partner very closely with the regulatory body and the healthcare system, so they test out the systems much earlier in [real-world] cases. Asia has a big population base, both for validating devices and having digital innovation. It makes it much more feasible to enforce that kind of clinical trial in real time,” he said. “That makes wearable devices very affordable and very easy for us to try and obtain.”

Khong’s breakdown of Asian markets

Khong offered these summaries to help device manufacturers think about the Asian markets.

Rewards to reap

Medical device companies will likely face many challenges initially when they start their journeys to access Asian markets. But those that survive will reap the long-term financial benefits.

“Asia already occupies 60% of the global population,” Khong said.

In the medical device manufacturing category, Japan was the largest and India the fastest-growing market in 2024. On the basis of the therapeutic area segment, the cardiovascular devices segment held the largest therapeutic market share in 2024, while Asia’s surgical instrument segment is expected to grow the fastest during the forecast period, according to Grand View Research.

name: Adobe
title: Adobe Digital Insights UK Online Spending - Holiday and Full Year 2025
description:
New data from Adobe Digital Insights, powered by Adobe Analytics, shows that, during November and December 2025, UK shoppers splashed a record £26.9 billion online (up 4.1% from 2024), signalling the highest online spending Christmas period on record.
Across 2025, online spend reached £118.5 billion, up 2.8% on 2024 – another record-breaker.
Mobile experience still makes or breaks conversion Clearly, GenAI is setting the benchmark for how quickly online shoppers expect to move.
Our data shows that when the price is right, shoppers are happy to trade-up to more premium items.
As the Director for Adobe Digital Insights (ADI), he launched & spearheads the popular Adobe DEI (Digital Economy Index) & Holiday Retail reports, as well as other industry reports that profile emerging technology, creativity, and travel trends.
text:
January has a familiar feel. New Year’s resolutions, made in good faith, are beginning to wobble, and new gym memberships are already collecting dust. But behind a familiar start to 2026 lies a very different story about how a record-breaking 2025 ended.

New data from Adobe Digital Insights, powered by Adobe Analytics, shows that, during November and December 2025, UK shoppers splashed a record £26.9 billion online (up 4.1% from 2024), signalling the highest online spending Christmas period on record.

Across 2025, online spend reached £118.5 billion, up 2.8% on 2024 – another record-breaker. That annual growth may look modest at first glance, but it masks a strong finish.

The impressive performance over the festive period was driven by sharper discounts, budget-busting spending on key days, and a noticeable shift in how people researched and bought products.

GenAI is now part of the shopping routine

One of the clearest signals from this year’s data is how rapidly GenAI is moving from novelty to habit.

Traffic to retail sites from AI sources grew 329% year-over-year during the holiday period, with AI-driven referrals on Boxing Day up 685% on 2024 figures. While the overall numbers are still relatively small, the direction of travel is pretty conclusive: More shoppers are using GenAI tools to research products, compare options, and hunt for deals before they ever land on a retail site.

What matters more than where AI shows up is how it’s being used. Shoppers are increasingly trusting these tools to help them make informed purchases, using them to compare options, weigh up value, and make confident decisions before they buy.

As more AI services add shopping features and integrations, this behaviour is only going to accelerate in 2026. For retailers, that means visibility within these tools is becoming just as important as visibility in search or social feeds.

Mobile experience still makes or breaks conversion

Clearly, GenAI is setting the benchmark for how quickly online shoppers expect to move. By the time a shopper clicks through to a retail site from tools like ChatGPT or Gemini, they’re often already in ‘buy mode’. They’ve done their research, and the retailer’s site is purely for the purchase. Barriers to making the purchase, like long registration journeys or extra steps before reaching the checkout can quickly kill this positive momentum and see the sale head somewhere else.

Our research shows many of these journeys are now happening on mobile. During the holiday period, £16.5 billion was spent on mobile devices, rising 14.1% from 2024 and accounting for 61.5% of total online spend. While online spending on mobile devices has outstripped desktop or laptop spending in the UK for several years, the rise of GenAI search means the context has changed. Mobile experiences now need to match the speed and simplicity of the discovery tools (increasingly GenAI) that lead shoppers there in the first place.

Big sales days inspire shopper confidence

Black Friday once again stood out as the single biggest online shopping day of the year, with £1.16 billion spent. Cyber Weekend delivered £3.8 billion, and Boxing Day passed £500 million as shoppers shifted from buying gifts for others to searching for gifts for themselves.

What makes these ‘eventised’ shopping moments most interesting is the behaviour behind them. Across the year, consumers are highly price driven, often trading down and searching for the cheapest option. During the holiday period, and especially on major sales days, that mindset shifts.

Our data shows that when the price is right, shoppers are happy to trade-up to more premium items. The deeper discounts on offer over the holiday period and the increased sense of urgency over Cyber Weekend, prompted shoppers to go for the best they could afford rather than the cheapest they could find. Across November and December Adobe Analytics data shows the share of the most expensive items sold across different categories was 14% higher compared with the rest of 2025.

Where UK retailers stand heading into 2026

The UK retail picture at the end of 2025 is one of deliberate, informed shoppers who are ready to spend (and in some cases, spend big), but only when the conditions, value and experience feels right. Retailers that understand those moments and meet those expectations will be set up for success in 2026.

You can find these insights and more here.

Vivek is a leading insights analyst who has worked with some of the largest CPG & Technology organizations, in the world, to drive key digital marketing & data science initiatives. As the Director for Adobe Digital Insights (ADI), he launched & spearheads the popular Adobe DEI (Digital Economy Index) & Holiday Retail reports, as well as other industry reports that profile emerging technology, creativity, and travel trends. Prior to joining Adobe, Vivek worked with E. & J. Gallo, where he was part of their Consumer & Product Insights Group, advising brands on how to track and measure the impact of global marketing campaigns. Additionally, Vivek has lead data science teams to develop effective propensity models and automate digital campaign management. Vivek holds a MS in Predictive Analytics and Data Science from Northwestern University and BBA from Georgia State University.

name: J&J
title: 'It's silently killing people' | The Plumas Sun
description:
The Plumas County Public Health Agency immediately went to work.
It stocked up on naloxone (Narcan), a drug that reverses an opioid-related overdose, said former Plumas County Public Health Agency Director Andrew Woodruff.
The opioid epidemic of today is “silently killing people.” Gary Sanderson, Plumas County alcohol and drug administrator Sanderson said the opioid epidemic of today is “silently killing people.” As these new challenges arose, Reinert said county health officials began implementing programs for medication-assisted treatment, syringe exchange and substance-use disorder counseling.
“It’s kind of a blessing in disguise.” Nicole Reinert, Plumas County Public Health Agency director “It’s kind of a blessing in disguise,” Reinert said.
Blust explained that Westwood is included in the Plumas County data despite being part of Lassen, not Plumas County.
text:
Fifteen years ago, Plumas County had one of California’s highest rates of opioid prescriptions, as well as one of the highest overdose death rates. By 2016, prescriptions were down and the death rate followed. That year zero opioid-related deaths were reported.

This positive statistical trend, however, masks an uncomfortable local reality: Since 2016, Plumas County’s opioid epidemic has shifted from legal prescriptions to underground sources, and the death rate has begun to rise. That is driving public health officials to adjust their approach.

Responding to the spotlight

The community of just under 20,000 residents came under an opioid epidemic spotlight after data compiled from the California Department of Public Health, from 2009 to 2013, found that Plumas County had the highest death rate of deaths from prescribed opioids in the state. The worst year was 2010 with a rate of 40.16 per 100,000 residents, according to the California Overdose Surveillance Dashboard.

The Plumas County Public Health Agency immediately went to work. It launched a campaign to add education around opioids in schools and in the community. It stocked up on naloxone (Narcan), a drug that reverses an opioid-related overdose, said former Plumas County Public Health Agency Director Andrew Woodruff.

In 2015, the county had strengthened its efforts to combat the local epidemic through collaboration with Modoc, Lassen and Sierra counties. They formed the Northern Sierra Opioid Coalition in January 2016. The coalition implemented a series of programs, said Woodruff. Among them were educating the community and prescribers about opioids, and handing out more free naloxone.

Pharmacies and hospitals got on board, working together to implement a prescription drug monitoring program, said Plumas County Public Health Agency Director Nicole Reinert. They created a database so the various pharmacies and hospitals can monitor prescriptions to avoid misuse.

The impacts were almost immediate: In 2016 zero deaths related to opioids were reported; only one death was reported the following year.

Going underground

Then something shifted. While opioid prescriptions continue to fall, deaths began to rise. From 2017-2021, death rates bounced between one and two annually. In both 2022 and 2023 three deaths were reported. In 2024 there were four. Public health officials attribute this in part to the way the epidemic has changed as prescriptions dropped.

“It started from overprescribing,” said Reinert. When intervention programs reduced that availability, people turned to illicit street drugs. They had no legal source to feed their addiction, she said, “and now we’re seeing fentanyl.”

While fentanyl is new to the area, methamphetamine has been prevalent for decades. As prescriptions for opioids have fallen, these two drugs are showing up together, said Gary Sanderson, Plumas County’s alcohol and drug administrator.

“A lot of the methamphetamine is causing people to test positive for fentanyl as well,” he said. Non-prescription methamphetamine is increasingly laced with fentanyl. “With more fentanyl in the meth, there is a higher risk to the community for overdose deaths,” Sanderson added.

Fentanyl, a synthetic opioid, has a very high potency that can be fatal even in low amounts. Sanderson said he doesn’t believe that people go straight to heroin or meth. “Typically individuals might go to the black market, through friends or connections, to find the same prescriptions they were being given before,” he said.

Some people have told him the drugs they bought through the black market weren’t the same as the ones being prescribed, potentially leading to addiction to other substances, Sanderson said.

The opioid epidemic of today is “silently killing people.”

Gary Sanderson, Plumas County alcohol and drug administrator

Sanderson said the opioid epidemic of today is “silently killing people.”

As these new challenges arose, Reinert said county health officials began implementing programs for medication-assisted treatment, syringe exchange and substance-use disorder counseling. But funding and resources posed a challenge as they worked to expand access and care.

$6.9 million opioid settlement

In 2018, Plumas joined other counties and cities across California to sue pharmaceutical companies and drugstores who were “accused of misleading marketing practices,” Reinert said. Among them were Johnson and Johnson, Teva, Allergen, Wallgreens, Wallmart, CVS and Kroger, Reinert said.

They won. The financial award from these lawsuits, which is dispersed in annual allotments, can only be spent on mitigating the opioid epidemic. The first of the funds came in late 2022. The county expects to receive a total of $6.9 million over an 18-year span, Reinert said.

But the funds, overseen by the county administration officer, sat untouched from 2022 until Reinert’s appointment in April 2024. The public health agency had no permanent director during that period, part of a spate of department head vacancies that peaked at 19 of 26 positions between 2020 and 2022. Six department heads submitted their resignations between June and September 2023.

The initial installment of settlement funds built interest over the two years, reaching $2 million by the time Reinert assumed her role as director. She immediately requested oversight of the fund.

“It’s kind of a blessing in disguise.”

Nicole Reinert, Plumas County Public Health Agency director

“It’s kind of a blessing in disguise,” Reinert said. “We’re now able to work systematically in the county to distribute it with this large amount.”

Reinert and her team gathered data and reached out to partners for the best way to spend the money. Almost immediately, she put some into the Plumas County Behavioral Health Department’s wellness centers, which were struggling financially at the time. The Chester and Quincy wellness centers provide community assistance programs, such as help with applications, wellness groups and counseling, and financial assistance. They also contain Haven machines, which offer harm reduction tools. These machines are being stocked partially through funding from the settlement.

The public health department is working to help expand services at the Plumas County Intervention and Resource Center through North Star Navigation Center, PCIRC’s shelter service.

Reinert and Sanderson noted that transportation, time and access to services can be challenging for some people. Reinert intends to use some of the settlement funds to hire a nurse to provide education and wound care via a mobile outreach van. She also plans to use some of the settlement funds for transportation to treatment centers.

“These are really remote sites that often don’t get a lot of services at all,” Reinert said. “We’re trying to meet them where they’re at and trying to expand.”

Reinert also plans to put part of the settlement funding toward support for incarcerated individuals. People suspected of being under the influence may soon have a medical wristband to monitor signs of an overdose, allowing health officials to react quickly.

“The [Plumas] jail is working to purchase a body scanner upon entry, just to ensure there aren’t additional substances,” Reinert said. “If these substances are found, this will not be additional tools for prosecution — this is simply for prevention.”

After people are released from jail, public health officials hope to offer Brixadi, a once-a-month injection used to treat moderate to severe opioid addiction. There is also a fund for people who can’t afford treatment, Sanderson said.

Naloxone (Narcan)

When the opioid epidemic was first identified, one of the earliest public health interventions focused on training the community to use naloxone.

Public Health Coordinator Danielle Blust explained that the stigma surrounding naloxone has remained throughout this process. Some believe that offering naloxone encourages users to continue taking opioids. Other forms of stigma include people believing they don’t need naloxone because of who the drug is intended for.

Blust explained why everyone — with or without addiction issues — should have naloxone: “It isn’t just people who take drugs recreationally, but also those who take them because of their health.”

Blust and Reinert both compared naloxone to a fire extinguisher: “Everyone should have one at their house,” Blust said. “You never want to use it, but you’ll be grateful to use it when you have it.”

“You never want to use it, but you’ll be grateful to use it when you have it.”

Danielle Blust, Plumas County Public Health Agency coordinator

Blust said that as community members, it’s important to know the signs of an overdose and to always carry naloxone. “If you notice someone’s lips are blue, or their skin is pale, or they’re having complications breathing,” those are all signs of an overdose, she said.

Naloxone is provided by the county public health department and the behavioral health department at no charge. The settlement money is also being used to purchase more naloxone.

Challenges in the data

The county public health department gathers the majority of the data on opioid overdoses. But gathering and interpreting data comes with its own set of difficulties. Plumas County has limited data for several reasons, including its small population, which makes gathering extensive information challenging. Other constraints include resources and staffing limitations, Reinert said.

As the epidemic has moved underground, often health officials have to rely on word of mouth.

“When we’re giving out Narcan through the harm reduction program, and people are reporting ‘I had three friends last week who overdosed and one died.’ That’s how, at times, our county has to gather some of the data,” Sanderson said.

Blust explained that when someone with underlying health conditions dies their death may be attributed to that health concern — even when opioid overdose plays a role. To make interpreting data even more difficult, the county’s size means that even one death can greatly increase percentages and change how the county compares with others, Sanderson said. The California Overdose Surveillance Dashboard isn’t completely reliable either. Blust explained that Westwood is included in the Plumas County data despite being part of Lassen, not Plumas County.

Sanderson was skeptical about the zero deaths reported in 2016. “I don’t think it was ever zero,” he said, explaining that the absence of deaths was likely related to reporting issues.

Reinert noted that the county’s epidemiologist has been looking at recent opioid overdose data. “We have collected local quantitative data through surveys regarding drug use, needs and readiness for treatment, which we are processing internally,” she said. This data will be paired with emergency room visits, uses of naloxone and monitoring vital statistics.

Looking forward

Plumas County remains under the state average for opioid prescriptions. But the wave of the underground epidemic has brought new challenges. With the opioid settlement money now being used, officials are optimistic that expanded services will bring positive change.

“This settlement funding is going to be a huge help for this community overall,” Reinert said. Without it, she was skeptical that any of the new programs could be implemented.

Sanderson said many people struggling with addiction feel judgment and shame, which keeps them using substances in the dark, stopping them from seeking support. He said that we need to begin looking at addiction as “a complex interplay between choice and disease.”

As settlement money funds more initiatives and projects, expanding access and care should help combat the opioid epidemic.

“I think we’re moving in the right direction,” Reinert said. “I see momentum not just with partners but with the community. We’re all going to have to work together.”

name: BNY Mellon
title: Dáil Éireann debate - Thursday, 15 Jan 2026 - Oireachtas.ie
description:
The response over the last two weeks has been chaotic and it has taken a Minister of State in the Minister, Deputy Burke's Department to actually cajole this Government into action.
I acknowledge the huge work Deputy Clendennen is doing in being a firm advocate for our small family businesses.
To support them, we also have bespoke schemes offered by Enterprise Ireland for cybersecurity, business consultancy and process innovation.
We have seen record growth among Enterprise Ireland companies this year.
We are aiming to bring approximately €2 billion into the economy through Enterprise Ireland high-value jobs and continued exports.
text:
I want to return to the issue of the fact that ten ministers have not paid back money owed to the public funds, in some cases tens of thousands of euro, seven months after it was requested. When I questioned Deputy Chambers, who is the Minister responsible for the NSSO, the body which will deal with these repayments, he said he is not privy to the interactions between Ministers and the NSSO and that he does not know the identity of the ten. The Minister has made a stout defence of the fact that those ten have not yet paid back the money. I want to put a number of questions and I expect direct answers. Does the Minister know who the ten Ministers are who have so far not paid back the thousands of euro they owe the public purse? How many of them are Fine Gael Ministers? From where was the information the Minister put on the record of the Dáil today in their defence elicited, if it was not from the individual Ministers? Crucially, when are the Ministers going to cough up and pay back the money they owe the taxpayer? I ask for direct answers please.

This is questions on promised legislation but I will respond directly to Deputy Doherty, as I have been very clear in relation to the NSSO. This is an error by the NSSO and Ministers are engaging with the NSSO. I do not know, nor should I know, the identity of anyone's payroll matters in the State. I do know from dealing with the NSSO because, as I said, between underpayment and overpayment everyone who served and gave a salary sacrifice in government, with regard to the decision to reduce salaries by 10%, was affected. This is why it is critical-----

In the week when special school classes were announced for 2026, I need to raise with the Minister the case of River Valley Community National School in Swords. It is not looking for a class in 2026; it is looking for a class now. This is in agreement with the NCSE. The school is a developing school in good but interim accommodation. It is being refused by the Department of education the provision of an autism class right now only because it is in temporary accommodation, even though it has the space. I ask, please, because I will continue to bring this up, will the Department meet the patron body and the principal on site to get this matter over the line? Autistic children are being let down, as are mainstream children and the staff. This can be resolved, please, Minister.

Compliance with the law is not a gift for X to give to this State but this is the benevolent tone in which it announced this morning that it will indeed comply with law in jurisdictions where that law exists.

This belated assurance for geo-blocking, which in itself is hugely problematic because it can be so easily circumnavigated, is too little, too late. It is not surprising that we are hearing this tone from this tech company because kid gloves is the approach that this Government and this State has taken to dealing with big tech and the harms it is wielding on society. The response over the last two weeks has been chaotic and it has taken a Minister of State in the Minister, Deputy Burke's Department to actually cajole this Government into action. I want to hear an update on what is happening with the Attorney General and his analysis of the law. I want to know if the Garda investigation, which we heard about yesterday in committee, has finally reached the doors of X on Fenian Street, and I want to hear what further Government action is going to happen so that we can take off those kid gloves and wrestle back control from big tech on the absolute havoc it is wreaking on society.

The Housing Agency is finding new ways to exclude people from the remediation scheme. We have already seen the system fail when pyrrhotite in concrete was ignored. The agency has now introduced a new method to refuse access, stretching IS 465 and selectively presenting facts. The approach will not withstand scrutiny and must be addressed. The decision has been independently reviewed by engineers and a legal expert, both concluding it is wrong. Reliance on an appeals process to correct such decision is reactive, costly and causes harm to homeowners. The Minister has the authority and responsibility to act proactively and treat the decisions as a test case and set a fair, consistent standard before people are affected. This matter goes beyond a single property. Now that this has been brought to the Government's attention, will the Minister intervene to stop this and review the test case or will it be allowed to continue? I want a simple "Yes" or "No".

Obviously, I am not the Minister for housing, but I will take this issue up with him. I would point out that the Government has been very proactive in protecting homeowners in Donegal. I acknowledge all those homeowners who have applied for the current scheme, which was enhanced, and the work done throughout our communities to ensure people and families are protected, because that is a primary concern of the Government for all those families that are affected in Donegal. I will raise the specific issue Deputy Ward brought up with the Minister for housing.

In Ireland, we use over 200 million single-use tea and coffee cups a year. That equates to at least 20,000 cups an hour. That is a staggering figure. Coffee cups are, according to Irish Business Against Litter, among the top five most littered items in the country according to a recent survey. Most of these cups cannot go into recycling bins because of the polyethylene lining used in the paper, making them non-recyclable. The Government had proposed a 20 cent levy as well as other measures. As the Minister knows, the litter issue is one thing, but the long-term environmental damage is another. When is the Government going to use or amend the Circular Economy and Miscellaneous Provisions Act 2022 to bring in a refundable deposit? Along with other products that I have referred to before such as the vaping material and nitrous oxide canisters, they are littering our country and we need to have something with a behavioural impact as well as increased fines.

In County Offaly, renewable energy developments are mainly located on peatlands around Rhode, Croghan, Edenderry, Banagher and Cloghan. These projects require abnormal load vehicles of up to 135 tonnes on 16-axle trailers. The damage caused by one trip of one of these vehicles is equivalent to one year of normal traffic. As a result, these peat-based roads now require annual maintenance, placing major pressure on our local authority roads budget and taking funding away from other roads that also need work.

Offaly has historically carried the heaviest load in providing power to this country and we are doing so again through renewable energy. We are simply asking for a fair crack of the whip and that separate, dedicated funding be provided to Offaly County Council for these road projects.

I am very proud to come from a small village called Kinnitty where we have benefited significantly from multimillion euro investment in the public realm, public services and the development of the Slieve Bloom mountain bike trails. However, in the last 12 months, we have lost our post office and our last shop, which had served the community for decades. Thankfully, a 68-year-old man, Mr. Jodie Flaherty, has stepped into the breach to open a new shop. However, it is a reflection of the challenges in the market conditions and trading environment for micro-businesses in small villages right across the country. I appreciate the measures the Minister has introduced through, for example, the local enterprise office in terms of supports, but there is a concern around viability. I ask the Minister and the wider Government to ensure there are further measures to make sure the viability of our micro-businesses in the best interests of our public good, our economic good and our social good.

I acknowledge the huge work Deputy Clendennen is doing in being a firm advocate for our small family businesses. I know, as Minister for enterprise, that they employ two thirds of people right across our community. We have taken a number of initiatives this year around viability and worked to ensure that they are more viable, including setting up our small business unit and working with our cost of doing business advisory forum, which is looking at the interoperability of regulators that are currently on our landscape and ensuring we are doing things faster and being agile as an economy. We also have a huge amount of work to do, as is outlined in the programme for Government, related to other viability measures. We will work with Deputy Clendennen to ensure our small businesses continue to grow. As I pointed out in my earlier contribution, all 13 sectors of the economy are in a strong growth phase right now.

Yesterday, the Irish Wheelchair Association and other disability organisations had a session in the audiovisual room. They gave some stark facts and figures to us. Sometimes, we all get lost in statistics and figures. The reality for people with disabilities is that they are affected far more by the high cost of living - approximately 16% more. They are in need of some form of a one-off payment now. This winter and the next few months can be severe and extremely cold. At present, they are receiving huge electricity and gas bills, some up to €500. They told us they were in a position where they had to give up a few meals a week to heat their homes and stop their home dialysis treatment and go to their local hospital to save on their electricity bills. There are a few cases where they stopped recharging their mobile wheelchairs.

I ask that the Government consider a one-off targeted payment of €400, with an estimated cost of €145 million. Considering the surplus billions of euro that is in the coffers at the moment, it is a very modest ask for the most vulnerable people in the country. As they say themselves, they are 22% of the invisible minority.

During Leaders' Questions, I raised quite clearly what the Government was doing for people who were most vulnerable, particularly the 15% increase in our fuel allowance, of which one in four households is now in receipt of, to reflect the challenges related to the cost of living. I also mentioned the social welfare increase for carers, those with disabilities and those on the margins of society of €10 per week. There are further interventions that assist people through the social welfare code. I always point out that the community welfare office is ready to assist people if they have any one-off shocks or meet a liability they are unable to discharge. I assure people that the Government will continue to work to support people with disabilities. In 2026, we have a record budget for disability services - this is a fact - and the Government wants to continue to support that sector.

The importance of public transport and connectivity in rural areas cannot be emphasised strongly enough. In that regard, I acknowledge the tremendous work of Alan O'Connell, manager of Kerry Local Link, and his staff. As a councillor, I called a number of years ago for a hop-on, hop-off bus service on the Ring of Kerry. Today, thankfully, there are several buses going in both directions but there is a great need for additional routes. The tender process for the Killarney to Mallow route is complete and we await funding.

I will raise three other important routes: Beaufort to Killorglin via Whitefield; Kate Kearney's Cottage at the world-famous tourist attraction, the Gap of Dunloe, to Beaufort village and on to Killarney town; and from Dooks in Glenbeigh to Cromane and on to Killorglin town. Will the Minister ask the Minister for Transport to allocate the necessary funding to the NTA for the Connecting Ireland mobility scheme to allow these important routes to proceed?

The Deputy is right to highlight the opportunity Mallow presents and has presented for some time to HSE south west to provide step-down facilities and other healthcare facilities, particularly to help with the discharge from Mercy and Cork University Hospital. There have been beds there that have been available. I am having a full seminar with HSE south west on 5 February, when I will go through all of that in detail, including making sure all the beds funded are opened on time and in a timely way, as well as making sure all discharge pathways that currently exist are being fully utilised by all model 3 and model 4 hospitals there.

I am supporting a local family in Drogheda in dire straits because of a mind-boggling decision made by the National Council for Special Education, NCSE, to bring forward an arbitrary deadline of 1 October for parents seeking special class or special school placement for their child in the upcoming academic year. Eight-year-old Alfie has a diagnosis of developmental language disorder and global delay sensory overload which means he cannot deal with change, has issues eating and drinking, needs help with toileting, wets and soils himself regularly and has severe anxiety and stress along with no sense of danger. He has been hospitalised owing to stress responses and mental health difficulties. The challenges he faces have increased since moving to mainstream education and his mam advises that only following hospital admissions in early October did she begin pushing for special class placement and learned of this deadline. They have secured a place in a special class in a different school that would meet Alfie's needs but the application could not be completed without a letter of eligibility from the NCSE. The school closes to applications tomorrow.

I do not like raising individual issues on the floor of the House but, having contacted the local SENO and the NCSE to plead for flexibility in the deadline, I have been told the facility to issue the letter of eligibility has ended. It is completely unacceptable the NCSE's refusal to issue a letter of eligibility will mean Alfie or any other child could not complete an application for a special school placement. For the sake of these vulnerable children, this arbitrary deadline needs to be scrapped.

My office has been inundated with telephone calls from worried carers in receipt of carer's benefit and carer's allowance. A number of them received letters from the Revenue this week and last week telling them they are liable for tax. Does the Minister accept many of these carers were unaware there was a tax payment due or a burden upon them? Will his Department consider exemptions and thresholds for transition and protection of carers affected to ensure they are not penalised. Carers are among the most vulnerable people in our community. The Minister mentioned how big our welfare system is and how big the budget is. I find it entirely unfair people who are giving up and sacrificing and are getting out of the house to get a break for a couple of hours while caring for and committing to their families are receiving worrying letters from Revenue saying they are being audited, owe tax and will be paying tax on their carer's benefit or carer's allowance.

I thank the Deputy for raising this very important issue. I am a firm advocate for carers. We in society owe a huge debt for the work they do. That is why the Government is responding through supports and is on a trajectory to abolishing the means test for carer's allowance to demonstrate our support for the sector. The taxation is based on other income people may have received. The Taoiseach has sought a briefing on this. It was raised in the House earlier this week. We can revert to the Deputy in due course.

In December the IDA published its annual results for 2025, stating it has secured a record 323 investment proposals, representing a 38% increase on the previous year, and expected to deliver over 15,000 new jobs. In Wexford last year, Bank of New York Mellon disposed of 310 highly skilled jobs. The workers lost their jobs and the offices are on the market in an IDA business park in Wexford town. This is an ideal opportunity to acquire a really good suite of offices in a building that an IDA company could move into. I urge the Minister to impress upon the IDA to purchase this building and secure employment - perhaps replacement employment for the 310 workers of BNY Mellon who lost their jobs in Wexford.

I thank the Deputy for raising this very important matter. I assure him the IDA is liaising with BNY on the building and a future occupant for it. That will be to the forefront for any building that becomes vacant because of a change in operations, like BNY had in terms of its consolidation. We will do everything we can to get a replacement tenant in it. One of the things I am really driving the IDA on is the dispersement of jobs. We need to see a strong proportion going to regional areas. It has hit 56% or 57% and we hope that will continue throughout the remaining four years of the current strategy.

I raise the horrific case of a peaceful working family in Finglas who suffered the terrible trauma of being petrol bombed out of their home. Their house was destroyed in the arson attack and they just made it out alive because of the brave actions of one of the children, Amanda Uwase, who is in the Gallery today. She went back into the burning home and rescued her younger brothers and sister. Her mother works as a carer and was rescued by the fire services. However, the response from the Government and the State to this terrible attack on peaceful working people in Finglas has been absolutely outrageous in its silence. The family has been left homeless. This is not good enough. Where is the response from the Minister for justice to find the perpetrators, bring them to justice and be tough on such a heinous crime? Is the lack of response because these are disadvantaged communities?

I want to acknowledge Amanda's presence and say how proud of her I am. I saw her report on the news. The work she has done in tertiary education has been exemplary. As an Irish Government Minister, I want to say that she and her family are really welcome in our country. My heart goes out to her on what she has had to experience.

I will say to Amanda that we have an independent justice system in our country. I absolutely assure her that An Garda Síochána will investigate this heinous crime in full and ensure that someone is brought to justice for it. I also acknowledge the huge contribution that people who come from many different countries make in ours. I am very proud of the one in five people working in our economy right now who were not born in Ireland. They make a contribution to our healthcare and hospitality sectors. Many of them keep the cornerstones of our economy together. Amanda, you are very brave. Keep the faith. This country will have your back.

Families in Kildare North are still reporting that their children do not have confirmed secondary school places for September. This is despite the apply to school pilot programme the Minister for education introduced in Celbridge and other locations around the country to provide earlier clarity and reduce duplicate applications. The overlap between towns in Kildare North is delaying offers and leaving parents and, more importantly, sixth class children in complete uncertainty. If this pilot is genuinely producing more robust data, then that information needs to be used to identify where additional capacity is required. This is particularly pertinent to Maynooth Community College, Maynooth Post Primary School and Salesian College Celbridge. I ask the Minister to ask the Department of education and the Minister how the data from the apply to school pilot is being used to ensure that the children still awaiting places in Kildare North receive timely offers and how it will inform capacity planning moving forward.

What specific measures are the Minister's Department and Enterprise Ireland undertaking to ensure that SMEs in Ireland stay up to date with advancements in AI and digital technologies as they grow at a rapid rate? Local enterprise offices, LEOs, have been very good at giving grants to small companies but what I am talking about are mid-range SMEs that would like to get involved with Enterprise Ireland but sometimes struggle to do so. What steps can we take this calendar year and next year as we look forward? These changes in our society are huge. Rapid improvements are being made and we need to get them into our companies to ensure that we stay in touch with technologies and companies from outside Ireland.

I thank Deputy Neville for raising this very important issue and for the work he is doing for the enterprise sector to ensure rewards for enterprise are very much embedded in our economy. A number of offers are currently going through Enterprise Ireland. We have doubled the value of the innovation voucher, which is a huge assistance with tertiary education. It provides for a great deal of the commercialisation of research that can be seen taking place in our economy. The grow digital voucher offers up to €5,000 for smaller businesses. To support them, we also have bespoke schemes offered by Enterprise Ireland for cybersecurity, business consultancy and process innovation. These allow businesses to see how bringing in artificial intelligence can result in greater productivity and, critically, allow workers to work on other areas, focusing on growing business and bringing more revenue streams into the economy.

We have seen record growth among Enterprise Ireland companies this year. Exports were worth €36 billion, which is something never heard of before. We want to continue that growth, add 75,000 additional jobs over the next five years and see growth in research, development and innovation, where the tax credit will help. We are aiming to bring approximately €2 billion into the economy through Enterprise Ireland high-value jobs and continued exports. I will work with the Deputy to help companies to start growing in scale through the schemes we have over the coming years.

I will try not to be.

How does the Government justify ploughing ahead next Thursday with a Bill that still allows the counselling notes of victims of sexual assault, rape and child sexual abuse to be accessed in trials despite all it has been told in recent months and years about how damaging and traumatising that is? I refer to the Criminal Law and Civil Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 2026. This provision should never have been contained in this Bill because it is such an important issue. It has been thrown in with pepper spray, street furniture and a million other things in order to get it passed. On 22 December, the Minister said that he was going to look at further amendments but the Bill has appeared with no further amendments. People are still going to have to choose between therapy and trial. The only change is that, instead of the person waiving their right, it will now be passed over to a judge for a disclosure hearing on whether the counselling notes should be allowed. This does not take away the chilling effect of your notes being accessed. It forces the victim to choose between proceeding with a trial or proceeding with therapy. It is absolutely disgusting that any law that allows this exists. The Government has had ample opportunity to outlaw it completely.

It emerged this morning at the meeting of the Committee of Public Accounts that there had been a significant overspend on an IT system for SUSI grants, which has now cost almost three times the originally budgeted figure of €2.2 million. The Comptroller and Auditor General drew attention to this at this morning's meeting. The project, titled "My SUSI", began in 2015 and by 2024 it had run to €6.4 million, although it is still only at the pre-project phase. What does the Government know about this? What oversight is the Department providing?

I understand this is an historical issue. As far as I am aware, there was a write-down on the project in 2021. Value for taxpayers' money is paramount. The project should deliver. As the Deputy has said, the project is ongoing. It is an important and fundamental system but it must be delivered efficiently in a cost-effective manner. I have asked for a full inquiry and will update the Deputy and the House as that goes on.

name: OpenAI
title: Ads Are Coming to ChatGPT. Here's How They'll Work | WIRED
description:
Pinterest Users Are Tired of All the AI Slop A surge of AI-generated content is frustrating Pinterest users and left some questioning whether the platform still works at all.
ChatGPT Disagrees Some AI chatbots have a surprisingly good handle on breaking news.
Tech companies are calling AI the next platform.
6 Scary Predictions for AI in 2026 Could the AI industry be on the verge of its first major layoffs?
IRL Cruising Is the Future Dating apps and AI companies have been touting bot wingmen for months.
text:
Pinterest Users Are Tired of All the AI Slop

A surge of AI-generated content is frustrating Pinterest users and left some questioning whether the platform still works at all.

The US Invaded Venezuela and Captured Nicolás Maduro. ChatGPT Disagrees

Some AI chatbots have a surprisingly good handle on breaking news. Others decidedly don’t.

AI Devices Are Coming. Will Your Favorite Apps Be Along for the Ride?

Tech companies are calling AI the next platform. But some developers are reluctant to let AI agents stand between them and their users.

AI Labor Is Boring. AI Lust Is Big Business

After years of hype about generative AI increasing productivity and making lives easier, 2025 was the year erotic chatbots defined AI’s narrative.

6 Scary Predictions for AI in 2026

Could the AI industry be on the verge of its first major layoffs? Will China spread propaganda to slow the US data-center building boom? Where are AI agents headed?

Save With Our Google Workspace Promo Codes for 2026

Boost your productivity and save with exclusive Google Workspace coupons from WIRED. Get up to 14% off plans for three months, including Starter, Standard, and Plus tiers.

Why a Chinese Robot Vacuum Company Spun Off Not One but Two EV Brands

The pivot doesn’t look out of place at CES, where Chinese electronics companies are increasingly applying their manufacturing prowess to new industries.

AI-Powered Dating Is All Hype. IRL Cruising Is the Future

Dating apps and AI companies have been touting bot wingmen for months. But the future might just be good old-fashioned meet-cutes.

OpenAI Invests in Sam Altman’s New Brain-Tech Startup Merge Labs

Merge Labs has emerged from stealth with $252 million in funding from OpenAI and others. It aims to use ultrasound to read from and write to the brain.

Google’s and OpenAI’s Chatbots Can Strip Women in Photos Down to Bikinis

Users of AI image generators are offering each other instructions on how to use the tech to alter pictures of women into realistic, revealing deepfakes.

The Danger of Reducing America’s Venezuela Invasion to a 60-Second Video

January 3 marked the return of US military intervention in Latin America. While the events unfolded between Caracas and Brooklyn, social networks had already fabricated their own reality.

name: Instacart
title: Instacart (CART) Faces Market Pressure from Uber-Kroger Partnership - GuruFocus
description:
Key Takeaways: Wedbush Securities expresses concerns over Maplebear's (CART, Financial) market position due to Uber's (UBER) partnership with Kroger (KR).
Wedbush Securities has raised concerns about Maplebear (CART), known as Instacart, due to Uber Technologies' (UBER) expanded collaboration with Kroger (KR).
This new partnership allows Uber customers to shop at approximately 2,700 Kroger stores via the Uber Eats app, potentially threatening Instacart's market share.
Despite continuing to support Kroger's same-day delivery, Instacart's dominance in online grocery may diminish as competitors like Amazon (AMZN) gain traction.
The company boasts a market capitalization of $10.45 billion, reflecting its significant presence in the online grocery delivery market.
text:
Key Takeaways:

Wedbush Securities expresses concerns over Maplebear's (CART, Financial) market position due to Uber's (UBER) partnership with Kroger (KR).

Instacart's market share in online grocery delivery is under threat from increasing competition.

Wedbush maintains an Underperform rating on Instacart with a $36 price target.

Wedbush Securities has raised concerns about Maplebear (CART), known as Instacart, due to Uber Technologies' (UBER) expanded collaboration with Kroger (KR). This new partnership allows Uber customers to shop at approximately 2,700 Kroger stores via the Uber Eats app, potentially threatening Instacart's market share. Despite continuing to support Kroger's same-day delivery, Instacart's dominance in online grocery may diminish as competitors like Amazon (AMZN) gain traction. Wedbush maintains an Underperform rating on Instacart with a $36 price target, as CART shares have dropped 11.5% in early 2026.

Maplebear Inc, operating as Instacart, is a leading grocery-focused delivery marketplace that connects national and regional grocers with consumers and couriers. The platform facilitates on-demand convenience for consumers, income opportunities for couriers, and digital scaling for grocers. Instacart's marketplace also attracts consumer-packaged-goods advertisers by leveraging valuable consumer behavior data. With approximately 600,000 shoppers and 1,800 retail partners, Instacart delivers to about 98% of households in the United States and Canada.

Maplebear Inc operates within the Consumer Cyclical sector, specifically in the Retail - Cyclical industry. The company boasts a market capitalization of $10.45 billion, reflecting its significant presence in the online grocery delivery market.

Financial Health Analysis

Maplebear Inc has demonstrated robust financial performance, with a revenue of $3.63 billion and a three-year revenue growth rate of 20.8%. The company's profitability is underscored by a net margin of 14.15% and an operating margin of 15.3%. Additionally, the gross margin stands at an impressive 74.46%, indicating efficient cost management.

Maplebear's balance sheet reflects strong financial health, with a current ratio of 3.64 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.01, suggesting minimal leverage. The company's Altman Z-Score of 6.52 indicates a low risk of financial distress. However, insider activity reveals a warning sign, with 21,495 shares sold in the past three months.

Valuation & Market Sentiment

Maplebear's valuation metrics suggest a relatively attractive entry point. The P/E ratio of 21.87 is close to its three-year low, while the P/S ratio of 3.14 and P/B ratio of 3.06 are near their one-year lows. Analyst sentiment is mixed, with a target price of $50.55 and a recommendation score of 2.4, indicating a moderate buy.

Technical indicators show that Maplebear's stock is currently oversold, with an RSI-14 of 32.81. The stock is trading below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages, suggesting potential for a rebound. Institutional ownership is high at 82.52%, reflecting confidence from large investors.

Risk Assessment

Maplebear's financial health is robust, with strong grades in financial strength metrics. The Altman Z-Score and Beneish M-Score indicate low risk of financial manipulation or distress. However, the company operates in a highly competitive sector, facing risks from new entrants and technological disruptions.

title: Fortune 500 Power Moves: Which executives gained and lost power this week (Jan. 10-16, 2026)
description:
This is Fortune 500 Power Moves, a column tracking executive shifts—from appointments and promotions to resignations and retirements—within the highest ranks of Fortune 500 companies.
Titles included in this roundup: CEOs (Chief Executive Officers), CFOs (Chief Financial Officers), COOs (Chief Operating Officers), and CMOs (Chief Marketing Officers).
We also include CTOs (Chief Technology Officers), Chief Information Officers (CIOs), CHROs (Chief Human Resources Officers), Chief People Officers, and Chief Customer Officers when there are Power Moves within the Fortune 500 announced pertaining to those roles.
